story.text: (Recasts lead paragraph, updates prices) By Chris ReeseNEW YORK Jan 3 (Reuters) - U.S. government bond prices rose on Wednesday on weak private-sector jobs data and minutes from the last Federal Reserve policy meeting that showed a central bank wary of slowing economic growth. Price gains were tempered, however, by a stronger-than-expected U.S. factory activity index for December. The Fed's concern over potentially slower growth, expressed in the minutes of its Dec. 12 policy meeting, helped to marginally boost investor expectations that the central bank may be considering the possibility of an official interest rate cut later this year. "One bullish item for Treasuries was that several members of the Fed monetary policy committee saw a 'subdued tone' to the economic data and thought the downside risk to growth had increased," said Cary Leahey, managing director at Decision Economics in New York. Leahey cautioned however that a good portion of the indicators released since the December meeting have shown an economy that is looking more resilient, and the central bank's concern over slowing growth was based on relatively old data. "The one headline that could be viewed as bullish for bonds is probably, correctly, considered by the market to be out of date," Leahey said. Benchmark 10-year notes US10YT=RR traded 5/32 higher in price for a yield of 4.66 percent from 4.68 percent late on Tuesday. Treasuries rallied early in the day after a surprise contraction in a private jobs report which hinted the nonfarm payrolls report on Friday could prove soft. After the data, economists at some Wall Street banks cut their forecasts for the government's nonfarm payrolls report. The ADP National Employment Report showed U.S. private sector employment likely declined by 40,000 in December, the first contraction since April 2003. "Clearly, going into the employment data this Friday, people coming into the New Year with a clean book would certainly feel that this (the ADP report) is something people want to be buying bonds on," said Michael Cheah, vice president and portfolio manager with AIG SunAmerica Asset Management in Jersey City, New Jersey. However, those early bond gains were later tempered by stronger-than-expected U.S. factory data. The Institute for Supply Management's December manufacturing report reading was 51.4, above the 50 mark that divides expansion from contraction. Economists had forecast the index would rise to 49.9 from November's 49.5 reading. Two-year notes US2YT=RR traded 2/32 higher in price for a yield of 4.77 percent from 4.81 percent late on Tuesday, while five-year notes US5YT=RR traded 3/32 higher in price for a yield of 4.66 percent from 4.68 percent. Thirty-year notes US30YT=RR traded 11/32 higher in price for a yield of 4.77 percent from 4.79 percent. (Additional reporting by John Parry and Ellen Freilich)
story.title: treasuries - prices rise on fed economic growth concern , jobs
